layout_description: The diagram illustrates the four stages of a Monarch butterfly's life cycle in a circular flow.

key_elements.name: Egg
key_elements.description: A small, pale yellow egg is shown laid on a green leaf.
key_elements.action: The life cycle begins with an egg laid on a leaf.

key_elements.name: Larva (Caterpillar)
key_elements.description: A larva, commonly known as a caterpillar, is shown munching on a leaf. It has black, yellow, and white stripes.
key_elements.action: The egg hatches into a larva (caterpillar), which eats and grows.

key_elements.name: Pupa (Chrysalis)
key_elements.description: A pupa, also known as a chrysalis, is shown hanging upside down from a stem. It is green and smooth.
key_elements.action: The larva transforms into a pupa (chrysalis), inside which it undergoes metamorphosis.

key_elements.name: Adult Butterfly
key_elements.description: An adult Monarch butterfly is shown with bright orange and black wings, and white spots.
key_elements.action: The pupa emerges as an adult butterfly, which lays eggs and continues the life cycle.

main_process: Metamorphosis: A butterfly undergoes complete metamorphosis, transforming from an egg to a larva (caterpillar), then to a pupa (chrysalis), and finally to an adult butterfly.
flow_details: The diagram shows a circular flow starting with the egg, followed by the larva (caterpillar), pupa (chrysalis), and ending with the adult butterfly. The adult butterfly then lays eggs, restarting the cycle.
overall_summary: This diagram depicts the four stages of a Monarch butterfly's life cycle: egg, larva (caterpillar), pupa (chrysalis), and adult butterfly. This process is called metamorphosis, where the butterfly changes drastically during its life.
